detailedSummary: Performance optimization creates fast, responsive web experiences. Core Web Vitals measure user experience: LCP (Largest Contentful Paint) measures loading speed, FID (First Input Delay) measures interactivity, CLS (Cumulative Layout Shift) measures visual stability. Optimization techniques include: code splitting reduces initial bundle size, lazy loading defers non-critical resources, image optimization (WebP, compression, responsive images), minification removes whitespace and comments, compression (Gzip/Brotli) reduces file sizes, CDN (Content Delivery Network) serves assets from nearby servers, caching reduces server requests, database query optimization improves data retrieval. Performance monitoring uses tools like Lighthouse, WebPageTest, and browser DevTools. Understanding performance optimization enables building fast applications that provide excellent user experiences and rank well in search engines.
whyItMatters: Performance directly impacts user experience and business success - fast websites have better engagement, lower bounce rates, and higher conversion rates.

quizzes.question: What does LCP (Largest Contentful Paint) measure?
options: Loading speed - time to render the largest content element
quizzes.explanation: LCP measures loading performance - specifically, the time it takes for the largest content element to become visible in the viewport.

quizzes.question: Code splitting increases initial bundle size to improve performance.
quizzes.explanation: False. Code splitting reduces initial bundle size by dividing code into smaller chunks loaded on demand, improving initial load time.

quizzes.question: What is lazy loading?
options: Deferring loading of non-critical resources until they're needed
quizzes.explanation: Lazy loading defers loading of non-critical resources (like images below the fold) until they're needed, reducing initial load time.
